categories.name: Natural Materials
categories.description: Materials found in nature that can be used with minimal processing

categories.name: Synthetic Materials
categories.description: Human-made materials created through chemical processes

categories.name: Composite Materials
categories.description: Materials made from two or more constituent materials

categories.name: Metals & Alloys
categories.description: Pure metals and combinations of metals with specific properties

categories.name: Ceramics & Glass
categories.description: Inorganic, non-metallic solids prepared by the action of heat

categories.name: Polymers & Plastics
categories.description: Large molecules composed of many repeated subunits

materials.name: Concrete
materials.description: A composite material composed of fine and coarse aggregate bonded together with a fluid cement that hardens over time.
materials.composition: Portland cement, water, sand, and gravel or crushed stone
funFacts: The Romans used volcanic ash to make concrete that has lasted for over 2,000 years
Concrete is the most widely used material in existence — almost twice as much concrete is used in construction around the world than all other building materials combined
The world's largest concrete structure is the Three Gorges Dam in China, which used 27.2 million cubic meters of concrete

materials.name: Steel
materials.description: An alloy of iron and carbon, and sometimes other elements like chromium, nickel, manganese, and more.
advantages: Can be alloyed for specific properties
disadvantages: Conducts heat and electricity (not always desirable)
funFacts: About 90% of all steel is recycled, making it the most recycled material on the planet
The Eiffel Tower's weight would be three times greater if it were built with iron instead of steel
Steel production accounts for about 8% of global CO2 emissions

materials.name: Aluminum
materials.description: A silvery-white, soft, non-magnetic, and ductile metal. Most abundant metallic element in Earth's crust.
advantages: Indefinitely recyclable without loss of quality
disadvantages: High energy required for initial production
Can be expensive compared to some alternatives
funFacts: Aluminum was once more valuable than gold - Napoleon III served state dinners with aluminum cutlery for special guests
The energy required to produce new aluminum from ore is 95% more than recycling existing aluminum
The world's largest aluminum structure is the dome of the Haydar Aliyev Center in Baku, Azerbaijan

materials.name: Plastic (General)
materials.description: A wide range of synthetic or semi-synthetic materials that use polymers as a main ingredient.
materials.composition: Various polymers derived mainly from petrochemicals
advantages: Durable and strong for its weight
funFacts: About 8.3 billion tons of plastic has been produced since the 1950s, with only 9% recycled
The word 'plastic' originates from the Greek word 'plastikos', meaning 'fit for molding'
The Great Pacific Garbage Patch, a collection of marine debris in the North Pacific Ocean, is largely composed of microplastics

materials.name: Wood
materials.description: A porous and fibrous structural tissue found in the stems and roots of trees and other woody plants.
advantages: Natural insulator for heat and sound
disadvantages: Susceptible to rot, insects, and fire
Limited span capabilities compared to steel
funFacts: The world's oldest wooden structure is the Horyu-ji Temple in Japan, built in 607 CE
Balsa wood has a density of just 170 kg/m³, making it lighter than cork
The bristlecone pine can live for over 5,000 years, making it the oldest living wood on Earth

materials.name: Glass
materials.description: An amorphous solid that exhibits a glass transition when heated towards the liquid state.
materials.composition: Silica (SiO₂), soda (Na₂O), lime (CaO), and various additives
advantages: Infinitely recyclable without loss of quality
funFacts: Glass is technically a liquid that flows extremely slowly - it's estimated to take over 10 million years for window glass to flow noticeably
The formula for making glass hasn't changed significantly in over 5,000 years
Gorilla Glass, used in smartphones, can withstand over 100,000 pounds of pressure per square inch

materials.name: Ceramics
materials.description: Inorganic, non-metallic solids made up of compounds like oxides, carbides, and nitrides, formed by the action of heat.
materials.composition: Clay, silica, feldspar, and various metal oxides
funFacts: The oldest known ceramic artifacts are figurines found in what is now the Czech Republic, dating back to 29,000-25,000 BCE
Modern ceramic materials can withstand temperatures exceeding 2000°C
Some advanced ceramics used in body armor can stop bullets better than steel at a fraction of the weight

materials.name: Carbon Fiber
materials.description: A composite material consisting of microscopic carbon filaments woven together and typically set in resin.
materials.composition: Carbon fibers (93-95% carbon) embedded in polymer matrix (epoxy)
funFacts: Carbon fiber is five times stronger than steel but weighs two-thirds less
A strand of carbon fiber is thinner than a human hair (5-10 micrometers)
The Boeing 787 Dreamliner is constructed of 50% carbon fiber composite materials

materials.name: Silicon
materials.description: A hard, brittle crystalline solid with a blue-grey metallic luster, primarily used in semiconductors.
advantages: Can be precisely doped with impurities
funFacts: Silicon makes up nearly 28% of the Earth's crust by weight, making it the second most abundant element after oxygen
Purified silicon for computer chips is 99.9999999% pure - among the purest materials ever made
The entire digital revolution and information age is built on silicon-based technology

materials.name: Titanium
materials.description: A lustrous transition metal with low density, high strength, and excellent corrosion resistance.
materials.composition: Pure titanium (Element Ti) or titanium alloys
advantages: Highest strength-to-density ratio of any metallic element
disadvantages: Reactive with some chemicals at high temperatures
funFacts: Titanium has the same strength as steel but is 45% lighter
It's named after the Titans of Greek mythology
The SR-71 Blackbird spy plane, which still holds the speed record for an air-breathing manned aircraft, was made of 85% titanium

materials.name: Cotton
materials.description: A soft, fluffy staple fiber that grows in a protective case around the seeds of cotton plants.
materials.composition: Cellulose (88-96%), Water (7-8%), Proteins and pectins (1-2%), Waxes (0.5-1%)
disadvantages: Heavy pesticide use in conventional farming
funFacts: Cotton has been cultivated for over 7,000 years
It takes about 10,000 liters of water to produce 1 kg of cotton
One bale of cotton can produce 215 pairs of jeans

materials.name: Rubber
materials.description: An elastomer characterized by its ability to deform and then return to its original shape.
materials.composition: Natural: polyisoprene from rubber trees. Synthetic: various polymers
disadvantages: Degrades with exposure to UV, ozone, and heat
funFacts: Charles Goodyear discovered vulcanization (the process that makes rubber durable) by accident when he spilled rubber mixed with sulfur on a hot stove
A rubber tree can produce latex for up to 30 years
During WWII, when Japan controlled most rubber-producing regions, the US government planted millions of Russian dandelions as an alternative source of rubber

materials.name: Graphene
materials.description: A single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a two-dimensional honeycomb lattice, the basic structural element of graphite, carbon nanotubes, and fullerenes.
materials.composition: Pure carbon atoms arranged in a hexagonal pattern
advantages: Strongest material ever tested (200 times stronger than steel)
Completely impermeable to most gases and liquids
disadvantages: Extremely expensive to produce at scale
Challenging to integrate with existing technologies
Potential unknown health and environmental risks
funFacts: Graphene is so strong that a sheet of it as thin as plastic wrap could support an elephant
A square meter of graphene weighs just 0.77 milligrams but could support 4 kilograms
The scientists who isolated graphene initially used adhesive tape to peel layers from graphite, a discovery that earned them the 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics

materials.name: Copper
materials.description: A soft, malleable, and ductile metal with very high thermal and electrical conductivity.
materials.composition: Pure copper (Element Cu) or copper alloys
advantages: Easily recycled without loss of properties
funFacts: Copper was the first metal manipulated by humans, and is one of the few metals that can occur in a directly usable metallic form (native copper)
The Statue of Liberty contains 179,000 pounds (81,193 kg) of copper
Copper has natural antimicrobial properties - bacteria and viruses die within hours of contact with copper surfaces

materials.name: Gold
materials.description: A bright, slightly reddish yellow, dense, soft, malleable, and ductile metal that does not oxidize in air or water.
disadvantages: Soft and easily damaged in pure form
Limited practical industrial uses relative to cost
funFacts: All the gold ever mined in human history would fit in a cube just 21 meters on each side
One ounce of gold can be hammered into a sheet covering 300 square feet
Nearly all the gold in Earth's mantle and core sank toward the center during planet formation - the gold we mine was likely delivered by asteroid impacts after Earth's crust had solidified
